text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 1    ICTs are defined by the United Nations Development Programme as “information-handling tools – a varied set of goods, applications and services
label: BODY

text: that are used to produce, store, process, distribute and exchange information.” UNDP, Information Communications Technology for Development.
label: BODY

text: 2    While there is no single definition of PPPs, this guidance note considers all types of partnerships between humanitarian actors and commercial
label: BODY

text: private sector partners, as described in the OCHA - DHL Deutsche Post report “Combining Capabilities”.
label: BODY

text: 3    For more on the private sector incentives to engage in humanitarian response, see the UN OCHA page on Engagement with the Private Sector.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH2

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH3

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN
label: HH1

text: PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH2

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations and the private sector regularly partner on initiatives that relate
label: BODY

text: to information and communications technologies (ICTs) and data. The most common types
label: BODY

text: of such public-private partnerships (PPPs) in this domain involve (i) financial contributions,
label: BODY

text: (ii) provision of technology, (iii) in-kind technical advisory support, (iv) joint technology
label: BODY

text: development, and (v) data sharing and collaboration.
label: BODY

text: •	 Data responsibility entails the safe, ethical, and effective management of data. This is often
label: BODY

text: overlooked or insufficiently reflected in the design of partnerships between humanitarian
label: BODY

text: organizations and the private sector.
label: BODY

text: •	 Existing frameworks for collaboration with the private sector should be enhanced with
label: BODY

text: additional considerations and practical measures to uphold data responsibility in partnerships
label: BODY

text: focused on ICTs and data.
label: BODY

text: •	 Common challenges related to responsible data management in PPPs include: (i) reputational
label: BODY

text: risk, (ii) effectiveness of technology; (iii) data sensitivity and use; (iv) uncertainty about new
label: BODY

text: data sources, (v) intellectual property, and (vi) dependency and deference.
label: BODY

text: •	 Recommendations for improving data responsibility are to (i) develop shared goals, (ii) conduct
label: BODY

text: robust due diligence, (iii) perform a risk-benefit assessment, (iv) structure partnerships through
label: BODY

text: appropriate agreements and (v) design technology responsibly.
label: BODY

text: PUBLIC-PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH2

text: Humanitarian organizations and the private sector regularly partner on initiatives that relate to information
label: BODY

text: and communications technologies (ICTs)1 and data. For humanitarians, such public-private partnerships
label: BODY

text: (PPPs)2 offer access to new areas of expertise and technologies with the potential to improve the efficiency
label: BODY

text: and speed of response. For the private sector, humanitarian partnerships offer access to new markets
label: BODY

text: and contribute toward corporate social responsibility objectives, among other benefits.3 Alongside these
label: BODY

text: expected benefits, such partnerships present a range of distinct risks related to data management.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: COMMON TYPES OF PARTNERSHIPS RELATED TO ICTS AND DATA
label: HH3

text: OCHA’s Connecting Business initiative (CBi) summarizes the state of PPPs as follows: “Despite a former
label: BODY

text: tendency for aid agencies to view businesses as prospective donors, their greatest direct contribution has
label: BODY

text: come in the form of new technologies and other innovations as well as the sharing of technical expertise.
label: BODY

text: Entire elements of humanitarian action, including cash transfers, telecommunications and logistics, have
label: BODY

text: been transformed as businesses have become increasingly involved.”7
label: BODY

text: There are five common types of private sector partnerships related to ICTs and data:
label: BODY

text: •	 Financial contribution: The transfer of funds from a private sector entity to humanitarian
label: HH3

text: organizations for specific deliverables, or the private sector’s direct sponsorship of an event or other
label: BODY

text: humanitarian activity.8
label: BODY

text: •	 Provision of technology: The free or subsidized (‘pro bono’ or ‘low bono’) offering of commercial
label: HH3

text: hardware or software for use by humanitarian organizations.9
label: BODY

text: •	 In-kind technical advisory support: The secondment of technical experts to support humanitarian
label: HH3

text: organizations to leverage ICTs and data in new ways.10
label: BODY

text: •	 Joint technology development: Private sector in-kind support to collaborative development of
label: HH3

text: bespoke ICT solutions with humanitarian organizations.11
label: BODY

text: •	 Public-private data collaboration: Making privately held data or insights available to humanitarian
label: HH3

text: organizations or as a public good.12
label: BODY

text: 4     In May 2019, the Centre for Humanitarian Data, in collaboration with Wilton Park, convened the Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action: From
label: BODY

text: Principle to Practice event to advance discussions around the responsible and safe sharing of data about crisis-affected people. This blog on the
label: BODY

text: outcomes of the event contains more information about three areas for collective action for data responsibility. In June 2019, Leiden University’s
label: BODY

text: Centre for Innovation, in partnership with OCHA and NYU GovLab, hosted the Data Responsibility Exchange focussed on PPPs in the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector. In September 2019, the Tilburg Institute for Law, Technology and Society convened a group of experts to discuss PPPs as part of an ongoing
label: BODY

text: collaboration with ICRC.
label: BODY

text: 5     Working Draft OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: 6    See the full remarks of the former Assistant Secretary-General at the High-level UN General Assembly side event on Partnering with the Private
label: BODY

text: Sector: How Data Can Improve Humanitarian Response.
label: BODY

text: 7    OCHA’s CBi currently supports 13 local business networks with over 500 private sector entities, combined. See also the United Nations Office for the
label: BODY

text: Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, “The Business Case: A Study of Private Sector Engagement in Humanitarian Action”.
label: BODY

text: 8    For example:  https://www.unocha.org/es/themes/engagement-private-sector/how-private-sector-helps-emergencies.
label: BODY

text: 9    For example:  https://www.devex.com/news/can-the-un-s-centre-for-humanitarian-data-stand-out-92435.
label: BODY

text: 10  For example:  https://services.google.com/fh/files/misc/accelerating_social_good_with_artificial_intelligence_google_ai_impact_challenge.pdf.
label: BODY

text: 11   For example: https://reliefweb.int/report/lebanon/2019-food-assistance-refugees-lebanon-lifeline-hope.
label: BODY

text: 12  For example: https://datacollaboratives.org/explorer.html.
label: BODY

text: Public and private sector actors have held a number of convenings and events on this topic, but there is
label: BODY

text: still no common understanding around the requirements for data responsibility in PPPs.4 While public and
label: BODY

text: private sector actors have held a number of convenings and events on this topic, there is still no common
label: BODY

text: understanding around the requirements for data responsibility in PPPs.4 Data responsibility in humanitarian
label: BODY

text: action is the safe, ethical and effective management of personal and non-personal data for operational
label: BODY

text: response.5 This guidance note provides an overview of the common challenges to partnerships related to
label: BODY

text: ICTs and data in the humanitarian sector, and it offers a set of recommendations to help humanitarian orga-
label: BODY

text: nizations and the private sector manage them more effectively.
label: BODY

text: “We must recognize that the private sector is in many respects more advanced
label: BODY

text: and experienced, and definitely faster when it comes to these issues. We need
label: BODY

text: the support of the private sector to accelerate our progress and take advantage
label: BODY

text: of new sources of data. This is especially true when we consider the potential
label: BODY

text: risks that arise with increased collection and sharing of data.”
label: BODY

text: - Ursula Mueller, former Assistant Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Deputy
label: BODY

text: Emergency Relief Coordinator6
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 13  See the European Parliament Study on Technological Innovation for Humanitarian Assistance.
label: BODY

text: FOUNDATIONS FOR PRINCIPLED PARTNERSHIPS
label: HH3

text: A variety of frameworks promote principled partnerships for humanitarian response (see the list below).
label: BODY

text: Similarly, many humanitarian organizations have processes in place for conducting due diligence before
label: BODY

text: establishing new partnerships. The following frameworks and principles are useful to reference in assessing
label: BODY

text: prospective private sector technology partners:
label: BODY

text: •	 UN Secretary-General’s High-Level Panel on Digital Cooperation
label: BODY

text: •	 Principles of the United Nations Global Compact
label: BODY

text: •	 GSMA Big Data for Social Good Initiative Sustainable Business Models Report
label: BODY

text: •	 World Economic Forum Principles on Public-Private Cooperation in Humanitarian Cash Payments
label: BODY

text: •	 The World Economic Forum and OCHA Guiding Principles for Public-Private Collaboration for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Action
label: BODY

text: •	 The UN Secretary-General’s Guidelines on Cooperation between the United Nations and the
label: BODY

text: Business Sector
label: BODY

text: These resources provide a strong foundation for developing partnerships centred around ICTs and
label: BODY

text: data. However, they can fall short in addressing issues specifically related to data responsibility. The
label: BODY

text: requirements for the safe, ethical and effective management of data in PPPs are not well understood and
label: BODY

text: thus not consistently addressed in these frameworks.13
label: BODY

text: CHALLENGES RELATED TO DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN PUBLIC-PRIVATE
label: HH2

text: PARTNERSHIPS
label: H4

text: The five types of partnerships identified above are characterized by a common set of issues related to data
label: BODY

text: responsibility. Six challenges are reputational risk, inappropriate technology, data sensitivity and use,
label: BODY

text: uncertainty about new data sources, intellectual property, and dependency and deference.
label: BODY

text: Each challenge is based on actual examples of PPPs related to ICTs or data. Given the sensitivity of these
label: BODY

text: cases, the subsections below describe the individual challenges in general terms. The matrix below
label: BODY

text: indicates which challenges are most common for either humanitarians, private sector partners, or both, in
label: BODY

text: the partnership types listed above.
label: BODY

text: Common data responsibility challenges in different types of public-private partnerships
label: BODY

text: Financial
label: BODY

text: contributions
label: BODY

text: Provision of
label: BODY

text: technology
label: BODY

text: In-kind technical
label: BODY

text: advisory support
label: BODY

text: Joint technology
label: BODY

text: development
label: BODY

text: Public-private data
label: BODY

text: collaboration
label: BODY

text: Reputational
label: BODY

text: risk
label: BODY

text: Inappropriate
label: BODY

text: technology
label: BODY

text: Data sensitivity
label: BODY

text: and use
label: BODY

text: Intellectual
label: BODY

text: property
label: BODY

text: Uncertainty
label: BODY

text: about new data
label: BODY

text: sources
label: BODY

text: Dependency
label: BODY

text: and deference
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Concerns for private sector
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: REPUTATIONAL RISK
label: HH3

text: Reputational risk can arise for a variety of reasons, including concerns that sensitive data may be shared
label: BODY

text: with third-party private sector actors or that data is not stored securely. For humanitarians, reputational
label: BODY

text: damage can occur if a private sector partner has been associated with human rights infringements in a
label: BODY

text: past project or is perceived to be ‘whitewashing’ by collaborating with a humanitarian partner. This can
label: BODY

text: lead to restrictions in access and erosion of trust with affected populations, which could undermine the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organization’s ability to deliver assistance.
label: BODY

text: INAPPROPRIATE TECHNOLOGY
label: HH3

text: Most off-the-shelf ICTs will not fully meet the requirements of a crisis situation. Humanitarian actors may
label: BODY

text: not have the in-house expertise needed to determine whether a solution is appropriate for a particular
label: BODY

text: context. Further, humanitarian data may be insufficient or incomplete for the analytical capabilities offered
label: BODY

text: by private sector tools. This uncertainty around the requirements for effectively deploying and using a
label: BODY

text: particular tool may deter the private sector from engaging in a partnership. A related concern for both
label: BODY

text: parties will be to maintain an adequate level of data security to prevent harm and ensure robust protection
label: BODY

text: of the systems and data involved in the partnership.
label: BODY

text: DATA SENSITIVITY AND USE
label: HH3

text: Private sector partners and humanitarian organizations may have different perspectives on the sensitivity
label: BODY

text: of data being managed. For humanitarians, data is considered sensitive based on the likelihood and
label: BODY

text: severity of potential harm that its exposure or misuse may cause to affected people, humanitarian staff
label: BODY

text: or the organization in a given context. For example, the locations of medical facilities may be considered
label: BODY

text: highly sensitive in an active conflict situation, whereas they can be publicly shared in a typical natural
label: BODY

text: disaster response. For the private sector, concerns about data sensitivity often relate to the proprietary
label: BODY

text: nature or value of data. Failure to establish a common understanding of data sensitivity and responsible
label: BODY

text: use at the outset of a partnership can lead to inappropriate disclosure of data or the use of data or insights
label: BODY

text: for purposes beyond the specified goals of the collaboration.
label: BODY

text: UNCERTAINTY ABOUT NEW DATA SOURCES
label: HH3

text: Humanitarian organizations may partner with the private sector to access new data streams, such as call
label: BODY

text: detail records, social media content or high-resolution satellite imagery. This data can be used to generate
label: BODY

text: information that is relevant to humanitarian response, but humanitarians may struggle to articulate a
label: BODY

text: clear question or topic of analysis. Humanitarians may also lack the expertise needed to understand what
label: BODY

text: insights these data sources can provide and how to utilize them responsibly. The limited familiarity with
label: BODY

text: private sector data sources and their potential use can cause hesitation among humanitarians to rely on
label: BODY

text: insights generated from such data. Similarly, private sector partners may not fully understand humanitarian
label: BODY

text: contexts in which their data could be used. Together, these challenges can lead to reticence and an
label: BODY

text: underutilization of private sector data.
label: BODY

text: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY
label: HH3

text: Intellectual property issues can create tension at the design stage of a partnership, as well as towards
label: BODY

text: the finalization of the partnership if the rights are not clearly defined at the outset. Private sector and
label: BODY

text: humanitarian organizations have different requirements and expectations in this regard, which may
label: BODY

text: be at odds with an effective and sustainable partnership. The release of proprietary and competitive
label: BODY

text: information that will endanger the company’s market position is a common concern from the private sector
label: BODY

text: perspective. Concerns also arise around ownership of humanitarian data managed or generated through a
label: BODY

text: partnership, particularly when the private sector actor could use such data for non-humanitarian purposes
label: BODY

text: (e.g. if a private sector actor uses data about household expenditure in a refugee setting for the marketing
label: BODY

text: of commercial products or services).
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: DEPENDENCY AND DEFERENCE
label: HH3

text: The power differential between humanitarian organizations and their private sector partners can cause
label: BODY

text: dependency on and deference to private sector experts in decisions regarding the design and
label: BODY

text: implementation of a partnership. This dependency is especially problematic in situations where private
label: BODY

text: sector partners initially offer an ICT product for free or at low cost and then start charging a fee at a later
label: BODY

text: stage. Lock-in or dependency on a single tool, service or partner can also undermine the sustainability and
label: BODY

text: effectiveness of humanitarian operations.
label: BODY

text: Deference to private sector experts on matters related to the handling of beneficiary or other sensitive
label: BODY

text: data may lead to greater exposure or risk than humanitarian organizations would normally accept. For
label: BODY

text: example, technical experts from the private sector may offer major gains in efficiency and targeting of
label: BODY

text: assistance through the use of advanced data analytics, requiring access to more granular beneficiary data.
label: BODY

text: Humanitarians may be tempted to grant such access without fully understanding the implications (e.g. the
label: BODY

text: likelihood of both the expected benefits as well as the related risks).
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN PUBLIC-
label: HH2

text: PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS
label: HH3

text: The challenges described above create reticence risk resulting in lost opportunities to deliver better
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response. The Centre for Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’) and the collaborators on this
label: BODY

text: guidance note recommend that humanitarian organizations and their private sector partners focus on the
label: BODY

text: following areas to improve data responsibility in PPPs:
label: BODY

text: 1. Develop shared goals
label: HH3

text: When designing partnerships, both parties should ask the following questions:
label: BODY

text: •	 What issues and current problem areas should we address together to meet a specific humanitarian
label: BODY

text: need?
label: BODY

text: •	 How can we create shared value?
label: BODY

text: •	 How can we be unique and set the collaboration apart?
label: BODY

text: •	 What existing work could the partnership support?
label: BODY

text: •	 Which capabilities and commitments are required from the different parties to achieve these goals?
label: BODY

text: 2. Conduct robust due diligence
label: HH3

text: Humanitarian organizations should use a vetting procedure14 to assess the private sector company’s
label: BODY

text: past and current partnerships, values, affiliations and reputation. This should include the impact
label: BODY

text: of fines or other regulatory issues previously encountered by the private sector entity, affiliations
label: BODY

text: with groups that do not uphold the humanitarian principles and other potentially damaging factors.
label: BODY

text: Building on the existing frameworks and processes mentioned above, organizations can ensure
label: BODY

text: that key considerations for data responsibility are included in standard due diligence practice.
label: BODY

text: Transparency regarding due diligence criteria and processes can help prevent reputational damage
label: BODY

text: by demonstrating a commitment to a robust review of new partners. Private sector actors may also
label: BODY

text: conduct due diligence when partnering with new humanitarian organizations.
label: BODY

text: 3. Perform a risk-benefit assessment
label: HH3

text: The expected benefits and potential risks of a partnership need to be defined and balanced against
label: BODY

text: one another.15 Doing this can help humanitarian organizations and the private sector to clarify
label: BODY

text: expectations and jointly design measures that will maximize benefits and minimize risks. Publicly
label: BODY

text: communicating the outcomes of a risk-benefit assessment can help build trust and improve public
label: BODY

text: perception of the partnership. It is equally important to communicate about the ways in which data —
label: BODY

text: especially beneficiary or other sensitive data — will be managed within the partnership.
label: BODY

text: 14    See for example the United Nations Global Pulse Due Diligence Tool for Working with Prospective Technology Partners.
label: BODY

text: 15  UN Global Pulse has developed a helpful Risks, Harms and Benefits Assessment Tool.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH2

text: JANUARY 2020
label: BODY

text: 4. Structure partnerships through appropriate agreements
label: HH3

text: The level to which partnerships should be formalized, as opposed to keeping arrangements informal
label: BODY

text: and flexible, is often not clear nor consistently applied across engagements. Creating an overarching
label: BODY

text: partnership agreement (e.g. through a memorandum of understanding) as well as more specific data
label: BODY

text: sharing or data transfer agreements can help clarify expectations.16
label: BODY

text: When formalizing the overall partnership agreement, parties should consult their designated legal,
label: BODY

text: technical and risk management focal points and consider the following issues:
label: BODY

text: a.   Overall goals of the partnership in concrete terms, with related commitments (activities,
label: BODY

text: outputs and key results) for both parties.
label: BODY

text: b.   Intellectual property restrictions regarding the future use of technology or insights developed
label: BODY

text: between the humanitarian and private sector partner.
label: BODY

text: c.   Mutual responsibilities for data management throughout the partnership, including
label: BODY

text: considerations for data sensitivity, data security and ownership, and retention and destruction
label: BODY

text: of data.17
label: BODY

text: 5. Design technology responsibly
label: HH3

text: Collaborative and iterative design or adaptation of technology can help ensure that tools and
label: BODY

text: platforms are fit for purpose in different response contexts. Organizations should allow for testing
label: BODY

text: and refinement of solutions in safe environments before deploying them in the field, and, where
label: BODY

text: appropriate, they should ensure a user-centred approach to how solutions are designed.18 Tools
label: BODY

text: should always be designed with privacy and data protection in mind. Positioning this kind of
label: BODY

text: responsible, value-sensitive design19 as a core component of partnerships can help draw attention,
label: BODY

text: build trust and even attract additional investment.
label: BODY

text: Contact the Centre at centrehumdata@un.org to share case studies of successful partnerships in this
label: BODY

text: space.
label: BODY

text: 16  For more information specifically on the mechanisms for data sharing partnerships, see the World Economic Forum report on Data Collaboration
label: BODY

text: for the Common Good. The Contracts for Data Collaboration project has compiled a repository of agreements for data-focused PPPs.The Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data is developing different templates for data sharing governance instruments, which are available upon request. Other initiatives
label: BODY

text: designed to facilitate different types of partnerships around ICTs and data include the OPAL Project and the GovLab Data Collaboratives Repository.
label: BODY

text: 17  Note that while data security measures are part of the solution, a different setup of a PPP (e.g. where less data is moving around) can offer an
label: BODY

text: alternative route. The GovLab at NYU has developed a helpful typology of such ‘data collaboratives’.
label: BODY

text: 18 “A user-centred approach is a creative problem-solving approach used to design products, services and programmes across a wide range of sectors
label: BODY

text: that puts the needs and experiences of intended end-users at the centre of the design process and engages the users throughout this process.” Sofya
label: BODY

text: Bourne (2019), User-Centred Design and Humanitarian Adaptiveness.
label: BODY

text: 19 See for example this report by the Overseas Development Institute, p. 27. For more information about ICT and Value Sensitive Design, see for
label: BODY

text: example this paper by prof. Van den Hoven of TU Delft.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'), together with key partners, is publishing a series of Guidance
label: BODY

text: Notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance Note
label: BODY

text: Series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through the series,
label: BODY

text: the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data responsibility
label: BODY

text: in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the European Union Civil Protection and
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY
